Judy wrties:
> --- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, "Gordon Mohr" <gojomo@a...> 
> wrote:
> > > i've also posted the virtual alexa and google comparison reports 
> in 
> > > the Files section (8host_reports)
> > 
> > Are those Google-comparison % figures the percentage of the Google
> > top-X that the named crawler got, or the percentage they missed?
> > 
> > - Gordon
> 
> Those are the number of pages that the named crawler got.

This does not seem to be the case. Looking, for example, at...

    percentages-googlemercator.txt 

...the first line is...

www.match.com              676     266143      0.25%    -265467

If "0.25%" is the percentage of the Google hits that Mercator
got, then we would assume Mercator got 0.25% * 625 = 1.5625
pages???

Clearly, the percentage is the lower of the two numbers shown,
divided by the higher, without regard to whether the same
URIs appear in both sets (union/intersection issues) or not.
(I don't think his isn't a very useful percentage number,
especially because its sense inverts based on which set is
larger.)

I can get the real number from the autosummary data:

www.match.com
                        google   mercator    Intersection      Union
URLs retrieved             676     266143              12     266807
Response codes:
  code = 200               676     257088
  code = 302                 0       8883
  code = 503                 0        172

If only 12 URIs are in both sets, the percentage of Google
top hits that are in the mercator data is 12/676 or 1.78%.

Clearly, something funky with the way the Match.com site does
things may make its URIs unsuitable for easy source-to-source
comparisons. (It appears to be the query-string 'trackingid'
appended to most of their page URIs.)

Looking at a less idiosyncratic site, the "percentages"
report says...

www.copyright.gov              1000       9690      10.32%      -8690

...but looking at the autosummary data...

www.copyright.gov
                        google   mercator    Intersection      Union
URLs retrieved            1000       9690             970       9720

... we see that Mercator actually got 970 out of 1000 of Google's
top hits, or 97%.

I'd like it if these more useful percentages were automatically
calculated in the autosummary reports. 

Specifically, when comparing the two URI sets A and B, we already
display:

   count(A), count(B), count(A-intersect-B), count(A-union-B)

We should add for convenience's sake:

   percentage of A also in B:
     count(A-intersect-B)/count(A)

   percentage of B also in A: 
     count(A-intersect-B)/count(B)

(When dealing with an artificially truncated set, like the
Google top-X, one direction of these two won't be very useful.)

- Gordon
